author: Lachlan Brown
title: If a man frequently uses these 10 phrases, he probably isn't a very nice person
text:
If a man frequently uses these 10 phrases, he probably isn’t a very nice person
We often judge people by their actions, but words can reveal just as much—if not more—about a person’s true character. In relationships, friendships, or even casual encounters, what someone repeatedly says can show us patterns of thought, hidden attitudes, and underlying values.
Over the years, through my own experiences (some not so pleasant), I’ve noticed that certain phrases are red flags. They might sound harmless on the surface, but when a man uses them often, they usually point to deeper issues—selfishness, manipulation, or a lack of empathy.
Here are ten phrases that, if repeated often, suggest a man might not be as nice as he seems.
1. “That’s just how I am.”
On the surface, this phrase might sound like self-acceptance. But in reality, it’s often a shield against accountability.
When a man frequently says, “That’s just how I am,” he’s usually avoiding growth. He’s excusing unkind behavior—sarcasm, temper, insensitivity—by pretending it’s part of his DNA.
I once dated someone who said this whenever I asked for a little more understanding. It wasn’t that he couldn’t change—he just didn’t want to. That taught me something important: kindness requires effort. If he won’t make any, you’ll be the one carrying the emotional weight.
2. “You’re too sensitive.”
This one stings, because it’s designed to shut you down.
When a man says, “You’re too sensitive,” he’s not listening—he’s dismissing. Instead of addressing the hurt caused, he flips the blame onto you. This phrase undermines your feelings and suggests that kindness is conditional on whether you can “toughen up.”
I remember a conversation with a friend who confided that her partner said this whenever she tried to express hurt. Over time, she stopped sharing altogether. That’s the danger—this phrase silences, and silence in a relationship is dangerous.
3. “Calm down.”
Said once in the right moment, maybe it’s fine. But when it becomes a man’s go-to phrase, it often signals condescension.
“Calm down” rarely calms anyone down—it usually has the opposite effect. It tells you your feelings are inconvenient. It implies you’re irrational, while he positions himself as the calm, reasonable one.
The kindest people don’t need to belittle your emotions. They validate them, even if they don’t fully understand.
4. “I don’t care.”
There’s a difference between being easygoing and being indifferent.
A man who often says, “I don’t care,” about your choices, your concerns, or your happiness is showing you exactly how little effort he wants to put in. Sometimes it’s about small things—where to eat, what movie to watch. But over time, the lack of care creeps into bigger areas: your dreams, your struggles, your well-being.
Kindness looks like caring, even about things that aren’t important to you personally. If he can’t extend that, it’s a warning sign.
5. “You’re lucky to have me.”
This one is pure arrogance dressed as a compliment.
A man who reminds you how “lucky” you are is telling you that he believes he’s superior—that your value depends on his presence. Nice people don’t keep score. They don’t remind you of how good they are; they simply are good.
I once had someone say this to me after he’d done the bare minimum—like showing up on time or remembering my birthday. Instead of gratitude, it felt like a threat: don’t forget what you’d lose. That’s not kindness. That’s control.
6. “You’re overreacting.”
This is another phrase that shifts responsibility.
When a man says, “You’re overreacting,” he’s telling you that your emotional response is invalid. Even if you’re passionate or upset, it doesn’t mean you’re wrong. This phrase often hides a deeper refusal to engage.
Kind people don’t measure your emotions on a scale and decide they’re too big. They meet you where you are and try to understand.
7. “I was just joking.”
Jokes can be playful, but they can also be sharp weapons.
When a man constantly falls back on “I was just joking,” after making a hurtful comment, it shows he lacks empathy—or worse, that he enjoys the discomfort. A genuine joke lifts the mood; a mean-spirited one cuts it down.
The worst part? If you call it out, he makes you feel humorless or uptight. But here’s the truth: kindness doesn’t hide behind humor.
8. “Why are you making such a big deal out of this?”
This phrase sounds eerily similar to “You’re overreacting”—but it carries even more dismissal.
By framing your concern as “a big deal,” he’s belittling what matters to you. Whether it’s forgetting an anniversary or making a hurtful comment, this phrase lets him minimize the impact while avoiding responsibility.
A nice person doesn’t measure whether your feelings are “big” enough. They just care that you’re hurt.
9. “That’s your problem, not mine.”
Independence is one thing; indifference is another.
A man who often says, “That’s your problem, not mine,” is telling you he doesn’t want to share burdens—even small ones. Life, especially shared life, is built on carrying each other’s weight sometimes.
I once had a colleague who loved this phrase. Anytime someone asked for help, he’d shrug it off. Eventually, people stopped asking. He thought he’d won some game of self-sufficiency, but what he really lost was respect.
10. “I don’t have time for this.”
Everyone is busy, but kindness makes time.
When a man repeatedly says, “I don’t have time for this,” what he means is, “I don’t have time for you.” It’s a way of saying that your feelings, needs, or concerns aren’t worth his energy.
Life will always be full, but nice people pause. They listen. They know that relationships aren’t interruptions—they’re the point.
Final thoughts
If you recognize these phrases, don’t panic. Everyone slips up and says something dismissive or defensive now and then. What matters is the pattern. If a man uses these words consistently, they form a picture of someone unwilling—or unable—to extend genuine kindness.
Here’s the truth I’ve learned, both in my personal relationships and by observing others: you don’t need to decode a man’s entire character to know if he’s kind. Just listen. His words will tell you.
And if you’re hearing these phrases too often, ask yourself whether this is the kind of energy you want in your life.
Because you deserve kindness that doesn’t need excuses, dismissals, or arrogance—just kindness for its own sake.
